messages.text: would it be possible to get that PR <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/34678> merged into 1.6? Especially since it is already tested, only consists of 1 line of feature (4 loc including tests) and has been approved by triage via the corresponding issue <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/34674> in march this year. (I don't know why the PR got its individual triage label :see_no_evil:)

messages.text: I don't much like it; a generator doesn't have keys. And if it does, you'd think those would be the values of the iterator, not the keys of the iterator. And arbitrary iterators have keys even less than generators do.

elements.text: I don't much like it; a generator doesn't have keys. And if it does, you'd think those would be the values of the iterator, not the keys of the iterator. And arbitrary iterators have keys even less than generators do.

messages.text: A generator, being a lazy map, does have keys IMO. Shouldn't generators be thought of as lazy maps?

elements.text: A generator, being a lazy map, does have keys IMO. Shouldn't generators be thought of as lazy maps?

messages.text: It doesn't behave like a Dict in any other way.

elements.text: It doesn't behave like a Dict in any other way.

messages.text: Arrays don't do either, do they?

elements.text: Arrays don't do either, do they?

messages.text: Arrays at least have indexing.

elements.text: Arrays at least have indexing.

messages.text: I wanted it to be on par with `map(f, iter)` so that map and Generator (or, soon, Iterators.map) could optimally be used interchangeably.

elements.text: I wanted it to be on par with
map(f, iter)
so that map and Generator (or, soon, Iterators.map) could optimally be used interchangeably.

messages.text: and yes, that also needs indexing

elements.text: and yes, that also needs indexing

messages.text: So it should also be a subtype of AbstractArray?

elements.text: So it should also be a subtype of AbstractArray?

messages.text: It should behave like one in all cases where its iterator is one

elements.text: It should behave like one in all cases where its iterator is one

messages.text: i.e. optimally it would mimic the structure of the underlying iterator

elements.text: i.e. optimally it would mimic the structure of the underlying iterator

messages.text: (as we already do for size, length etc)

elements.text: (as we already do for size, length etc)

messages.text: to make it a generic lazy map. Alternatively we could introduce a new lazy map type which is particularly designed to redirect structural requests to the underlying iterator

elements.text: to make it a generic lazy map. Alternatively we could introduce a new lazy map type which is particularly designed to redirect structural requests to the underlying iterator

messages.text: and maps value requests individually through the supplied function, no matter if requested via getindex or values or any other possible way

elements.text: and maps value requests individually through the supplied function, no matter if requested via getindex or values or any other possible way

messages.text: in a purely abstract matter it could work on anything that somehow pairs 2 values (=any association)

elements.text: in a purely abstract matter it could work on anything that somehow pairs 2 values (=any association)

messages.text: Well, I see we already define `axes` for it, which is almost the same thing. So perhaps we've already crossed this line anyway.

elements.text: Well, I see we already define
axes
for it, which is almost the same thing. So perhaps we've already crossed this line anyway.

messages.text: Though, it certainly would be nice to make some clear line decisions like whether Generator should be treated as lazy map and thus have all structure-preserving capabilities one would expect for a element-by-element mapping. And if so, then deciding if the mapping should be kept lazy and thus, applying another lazy map, will result in a generator with chained functions where changing the structure will only act on the iterator. Both will produce a new Generator object that subsumes all previous lazy maps. This needs a "pure" function to behave predictably, but that should be a requirement for lazy maps anyway IMO.

elements.text: Though, it certainly would be nice to make some clear line decisions like whether Generator should be treated as lazy map and thus have all structure-preserving capabilities one would expect for a element-by-element mapping. And if so, then deciding if the mapping should be kept lazy and thus, applying another lazy map, will result in a generator with chained functions where changing the structure will only act on the iterator. Both will produce a new Generator object that subsumes all previous lazy maps. This needs a "pure" function to behave predictably, but that should be a requirement for lazy maps anyway IMO.

messages.text: that at least would give a clear path on what else to add :smile:; or that we need any other type.

elements.text: that at least would give a clear path on what else to add
; or that we need any other type.

messages.text: for reference, maybe checK out <https://github.com/JuliaArrays/MappedArrays.jl|https://github.com/JuliaArrays/MappedArrays.jl>. I think this will likely serve you better than relying Generator as a lazy map.

elements.text: for reference, maybe checK out
https://github.com/JuliaArrays/MappedArrays.jl
. I think this will likely serve you better than relying Generator as a lazy map.

messages.text: <@U8D9768Q6> then we still should decide on what purpose Generator is for (since it's not meant to be a lazy map I guess) to finally clearly position on that line because such questions/interpretations keep coming up. Since we currently have Iterators.map == Generator and Iterators.map should be the lazy map (at least that's a reasonable expectation I guess) it's not out of nowhere to have that intuition IMO. That's why I alternatively suggested to add a new type which has that behavior and will be the default for Iterators.map in future.

elements.text: then we still should decide on what purpose Generator is for (since it's not meant to be a lazy map I guess) to finally clearly position on that line because such questions/interpretations keep coming up. Since we currently have Iterators.map == Generator and Iterators.map should be the lazy map (at least that's a reasonable expectation I guess) it's not out of nowhere to have that intuition IMO. That's why I alternatively suggested to add a new type which has that behavior and will be the default for Iterators.map in future.

messages.text: Maybe we should solve it the same way as missing/nothing. Introduce a new type to have a clear separation of meanings.

elements.text: Maybe we should solve it the same way as missing/nothing. Introduce a new type to have a clear separation of meanings.

messages.text:
Also, I'd guess MappedArrays.jl only works for <:AbstractArray while that proposed type should rely on julia's powers, i.e. duck typing, to do what we often consider to be very julian: Only restrict the argument types for dispatch and define the algorithm abstractly based on certain key functions. It'll work whenever those functions are available. A true pass-through type.
all these structural functions (size, length, keys, values, getindex, whatever) could rely on the duck typing here

elements.text:
Also, I'd guess MappedArrays.jl only works for <:AbstractArray while that proposed type should rely on julia's powers, i.e. duck typing, to do what we often consider to be very julian: Only restrict the argument types for dispatch and define the algorithm abstractly based on certain key functions. It'll work whenever those functions are available. A true pass-through type.
all these structural functions (size, length, keys, values, getindex, whatever) could rely on the duck typing here

messages.text: For a real lazy `map`, we should have `Iterators.map` be a separate function, then different iterators or collections can implement it to return whatever kind of object is appropriate, e.g. a MappedArray.

elements.text: For a real lazy
map
, we should have
Iterators.map
be a separate function, then different iterators or collections can implement it to return whatever kind of object is appropriate, e.g. a MappedArray.

messages.text: Oh good, it's already a separate function :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Oh good, it's already a separate function

messages.text: So, to rephrase my wall of text, I'm not hammering on making that type be Generator, just to clear the line and fitting Iterators.map appropriately

elements.text: So, to rephrase my wall of text, I'm not hammering on making that type be Generator, just to clear the line and fitting Iterators.map appropriately

messages.text: that being a separate function actually was your idea according to <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/34352|https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/34352> :joy: But there's also <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/34368|https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/34368> (which also has the triage label) pointing to the lack of proper extensibility because Iterators.map === Generator instead of Iterators.map(args...) == Generator(args...) because in the former way we add methods to the constructor of the Generator type and it would be weird to return a MappedArray etc from such a constructor.

elements.text: that being a separate function actually was your idea according to
https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/34352
But there's also
https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/34368

(which also has the triage label) pointing to the lack of proper extensibility because Iterators.map === Generator instead of Iterators.map(args...) == Generator(args...) because in the former way we add methods to the constructor of the Generator type and it would be weird to return a MappedArray etc from such a constructor.

messages.text:
This works:
```julia> Diagonal([I, I])
2×2 Diagonal{UniformScaling{Bool},Array{UniformScaling{Bool},1}}:
 UniformScaling{Bool}(true)                ⋅             
              ⋅               UniformScaling{Bool}(true)```

elements.text: This works:

julia> Diagonal([I, I])
2×2 Diagonal{UniformScaling{Bool},Array{UniformScaling{Bool},1}}:
 UniformScaling{Bool}(true)                ⋅             
              ⋅               UniformScaling{Bool}(true)

messages.text: <@U687RKK0E> for <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/18621>, should we remove the lowering optimization that rewrites `x -> f(x)` to `f` in comprehensions, since that’s semantically different?

elements.text: for
, should we remove the lowering optimization that rewrites
x -> f(x)
to
f
in comprehensions, since that’s semantically different?

messages.text: I'm not sure it's actually worth fixing. Another problem with it is that `f(_) for _ in x` works, and fixing it will turn it into an error. I think that's likely to break code at this point.

elements.text: I'm not sure it's actually worth fixing. Another problem with it is that
f(_) for _ in x
works, and fixing it will turn it into an error. I think that's likely to break code at this point.
